t: Romans 9
Israel’s Rejection of Christ
I*p tell the truth in Christ, I am not lying, my conscience also bearing me witness in the Holy Spirit,
that I have great sorrow and continual grief in my heart.
For I could wish that I myself were accursed from Christ for my brethren, my countrymen according to the flesh,
who are Israelites, to whom pertain*i the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the service of*i God,*i and the promises;
of whom are*i the fathers and from whom, according to the flesh, Christ came,*i who is over all, the*i eternally blessed God. Amen.
Israel’s Rejection and God’s Purpose
But*p it is not that the word of God has taken no effect. For they are*i not all Israel who are*i of Israel,
nor are*i they*i all children because they are the seed of Abraham; but, “In Isaac your seed shall be called.”
That is, those who are*i the children of the flesh, these are*i not the children of God; but the children of the promise are counted as the seed.
For this is*i the word of promise: “At this time I will come and Sarah shall have a son.”
And*p not only this,*i but when Rebecca also had conceived by one man, even*i by our father Isaac
(for the*i children*i not yet being born, nor having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to election might stand, not of works but of Him who calls),
it was said to her, “The older shall serve the younger.”
As it is written, “Jacob I have loved, but Esau I have hated.”
Israel’s Rejection and God’s Justice
What*p shall we say then? Is*i there*i unrighteousness with God? Certainly not!
For He says to Moses, “I will have mercy on whomever I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whomever I will have compassion.”
So then it*i is*i not of him who wills, nor of him who runs, but of God who shows mercy.
For the Scripture says to the Pharaoh, “For this very purpose I have raised you up, that I may show My power in you, and that My name may be declared in all the earth.”
Therefore He has mercy on whom He wills, and whom He wills He hardens.
You*p will say to me then, “Why does He still find fault? For who has resisted His will?”
But indeed, O man, who are you to reply against God? Will the thing formed say to him who formed it,*i “Why have you made me like this?”
Does not the potter have power over the clay, from the same lump to make one vessel for honor and another for dishonor?
What*ip if God, wanting to show His*i wrath and to make His power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath prepared for destruction,
and that He might make known the riches of His glory on the vessels of mercy, which He had prepared beforehand for glory,
even us whom He called, not of the Jews only, but also of the Gentiles?
As*p He says also in Hosea: “I*pn will call them My people, who were not My people, And*ld her beloved, who was not beloved.”
“And*ld it shall come to pass in the place where it was said to them, ‘You*ld are*i not My people,’ There*ld they shall be called sons of the living God.”
Isaiah*p also cries out concerning Israel: “Though*pn the number of the children of Israel be as the sand of the sea, The*ld remnant will be saved.
For*ld He will finish the work and cut it*i short in righteousness, Because*ld the Lord*sb will make a short work upon the earth.”
And*p as Isaiah said before: “Unless*pn the Lord*sb of Sabaoth had left us a seed, We*ld would have become like Sodom, And*ld we would have been made like Gomorrah.”
Present Condition of Israel
What*p shall we say then? That Gentiles, who did not pursue righteousness, have attained to righteousness, even the righteousness of faith;
but Israel, pursuing the law of righteousness, has not attained to the law of righteousness.
Why? Because they*i did*i not seek*i it*i by faith, but as it were, by the works of the law. For they stumbled at that stumbling stone.
As it is written: “Behold,*pn I lay in Zion a stumbling stone and rock of offense, And*ld whoever believes on Him will not be put to shame.”
